posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked:
Hey all, I’m in the midst of getting a new battery cart pulled together. Two questions I have are:

How do I go about mounting the SB50 connectors? I can’t seem to find any drawings on the Andymark site. Looking for drawings for hole spacing, and is there anything I need to consider when mounting these? Any clearances that are needed I should be aware of to allow the mating connector to plug in?

How do I go about mounting the SB50 connectors? I can’t seem to find any drawings on the Andymark site. Looking for drawings for hole spacing, and is there anything I need to consider when mounting these? Any clearances that are needed I should be aware of to allow the mating connector to plug in?

The lugs/contacts for the SB50 offered by Andymark show they’re meant for 6awg wire; A little heavier than the 18awg (14awg?) leads on our chargers. How do you go about crimping these contacts to such a small gauge? Normally on something like my car if the connectors I’m using are too large for my given wire gauge, I’ll just fold the wire over on itself a time or two. But there’s such a large difference here that I am hesitant to do this in this application.

The lugs/contacts for the SB50 offered by Andymark show they’re meant for 6awg wire; A little heavier than the 18awg (14awg?) leads on our chargers. How do you go about crimping these contacts to such a small gauge? Normally on something like my car if the connectors I’m using are too large for my given wire gauge, I’ll just fold the wire over on itself a time or two. But there’s such a large difference here that I am hesitant to do this in this application.

Any insight here is greatly appreciated, Thanks!

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
Check powerwerx for contacts suitable for chargers and Anderson’s drawing packages for the parts

https://powerwerx.com/anderson-power-powerpole-sb-connectors

I usually throw either a zip tie or a pair of # 6 wood screws through the holes in the connector

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
cad321:

Any clearances that are needed I should be aware of to allow the mating connector to plug in?

These are built in to allow the connectors to mate while flush with a surface, but not a bad idea to put in a 3/4” or so plywood offset to make removing the cable less difficult, or have the battery connector hanging off the edge of something.

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked:
Just had a look on the Powerwerx site and looks like there are “ reducing bushings ” available for just such an occasion. Also available at Digikey and Mouser by the looks of things, which will likely be much easier for us being Canadian.

Thanks for the pointer!

posts.name: Jon K.
posts.cooked: We use these ferrules on the battery chargers we sell. to do the reduction you are describing. We will strip double the length of the ferrule on the wire insulation, then fold over the wire, then crimp them with our industrial crimper approved by Anderson to create the proper bond on the wire for the contacts.

link_counts.title: 12 AWG Non-Insulated Ferrule Crimps - AndyMark, Inc
Battery Charger 3 Bank 6 Amp Dual Pro RS3 with SB-50A Connectors - AndyMark, Inc

posts.name: NathanNFM
posts.cooked:
cad321:

How do I go about mounting the SB50 connectors?

The SB50 connector has 2 clearance holes for 6-32 screws with a 0.75" spacing between them. They also have a 5/16" nut pocket on one side to hold the 6-32 nut. An example of this mounting is shown on this product .

link_counts.title: AM14U Family Vertical Battery Mount Kit - AndyMark, Inc

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked: Jon, do you have a minute to make a quick sketch? I can’t decide if those words mean it’s doubled or tripled inside the SB50 contact

posts.name: Jon K.

I apologize for the rough look to this, but it’s the best I could do without creating a work order and getting you an actual picture.

The left side is intended to show the double length of stripped wire, and the right is supposed to show it folded over the ferrule before inserted into the APP contact to be crimped. Ferrule 751×1124 332 KB
